3.11.20.1.2 (01-01-2023) Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS)
The SLA is located in IRM 25.30.7, Service Level Agreement between the Tax Exempt & Government Entities Division and the Taxpayer Advocate Service.
3.11 Returns and Documents Analysis

) The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), led by the National Taxpayer Advocate. Its an Independent job is to protect taxpayers’ rights by striving to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and knows and understands their rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR). TAS offers free help to taxpayers, including when taxpayers face ﬁnancial difficulties due to an IRS problem, when they are unable to resolve tax problems, they haven’t been able to resolve on their own, or when they need assistance to address an IRS system, process, or procedure that is not functioning as it should. TAS has at least one taxpayer advocate office located in every state, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico..

Taxpayers have the right to receive assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service if they are riencing ﬁnancial difficulty or if the IRS has not resolved their tax properly and timely through its normal channels. • Taxpayers have the right to receive prompt, courteous, and assistance in their dealings with the IRS, to be spoken to in a way can easily understand, to receive clear and easily understandable munications from the IRS, and to speak to a supervisor about inadequate service. declared disaster. For all extension requests with a late received date, C&E must review for a timely postmark date. a. The postmark date is the date the United States Postal Service or other designated delivery service has stamped the envelope to indicate the date the item was mailed. b. Receipt and Control attaches the envelope to any extension with a received date. If more than one extension request was included in an envelope, the postmark date is stamped on each additional extension. c. IRC

contains the “timely mailing treated as timely ﬁling/paying” This rule says to process any document or payment as timely ﬁled if it is received after the due date if the postmark date is on or before due date. d. If the request has a postmark date on or before the due date, the extension is timely ﬁled. Caution: When the due date falls on a weekend or holiday, process extension request as timely ﬁled if it is postmarked by the day that is not a weekend or holiday. e. Consider any postmark when making this determination. f. Process an extension with a timely foreign postmark as timely ﬁled on Rev. Rul.

Exception for weekends and holidays - if the due date falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the legal due date does not change. Process the extension request as timely ﬁled if postmarked by the next day that is not a weekend or holiday.

The postmark date is the date the United States Postal Service (USPS) or other designated delivery service has stamped the envelope to indicate the date the item was mailed. Receipt and Control attaches the envelope to any extension with a late received date. If more than one extension request was included in an envelope, the postmark date is stamped on each additional extension. IRC

contains the “timely mailing treated as timely ﬁling/paying” This rule says to process any document or payment as timely ﬁled if it is received after the due date if the postmark date is on or before due date. If the request has a postmark date on or before the due date, the
Example: If the due date is April 15, and April 15 is a Saturday, the extension would be timely ﬁled if postmarked by April 17 (the following Monday).

) Clear Code “C” is used for Error Codes when the error condition does not require a change or correction to the displayed record. The screen display will include a clear ﬁeld labeled “CL” to indicate the possible need of a clear code. (
) Error Codes are cleared by either correcting the condition or entering a “C” in Field CL to indicate no correction is needed. (
) Code “C” is also used to clear the action code from the screen after correc- tions are complete, or as with Action Codes
and

, the action code be cleared initially so other errors in the record can be resolved. The of the “C” with a priority I error indicates that you have made the corrections the action code and now wish to have any other errors on the record displayed. (
) The “
” is also used as a Clear Code when deleting action codes. It is used only for erroneous action codes when there is no reason to suspend the record. The “
” cannot be used in suspense correction. (
) Programming erases all “C” Clear Codes for Error Codes when a record is suspended with the CC SSPND. (

) Programming erases all “C” Clear Codes for Error Codes and Action Codes the new day’s Error Inventory and Workable Suspense Inventory. Unﬁnished records from the previous day will contain none of the “C” Clear Codes assigned to a record that was not completely worked. (

) Error Codes (including the ones that may require a “C” Clear Code) are numbered consecutively for correcting. a. There may be instances when you are correcting errors at the terminal and create an Error Code with a higher priority than the one(s) you have cleared with a “C” Clear Code. If this occurs, programming erases all “C” Clear Codes for Error Codes with a lower priority than the one created. b. Beginning with the higher priority Error Code you created, programming continues displaying Error Codes for the record. Screen displays with corrected data may often be different from those previously displayed. c. There may be instances when you will make a correction erasing an Error Code you previously cleared with a “C” and now the error condition no longer exists. If this happens, the “C” Clear code for this error and for all subsequent errors in the record are deleted. d. If after deleting the “C’s”, errors remain on the record, they are displayed for resolution whether they were previously displayed. (

) The “C” Clear code will prevent any other record corrections. If a correction must be entered but you have already transmitted the “C” Clear Code, and error is no longer displayed, then use CC GTRECW to make any corrections.
